content: I am a Postdoctoral Fellow at Harvard University working with Mor Nitzan and collaborating with Sergey Ovchinnikov. My research interests lie in the application of mathematics and physics to complex and biological systems. I am particularly interested in using machine learning tools such as autoencoders and natural language models for protein structure prediction and design, and for analysis of single-cell RNA data. Moreover, I am fascinated by the quickly developing self-supervised and reinforcement learning fields. I investigated policy gradient and Q-learning algorithms at Microsoft Research, Cambridge while finishing my PhD in Biophysics with Eric Lauga.
summary: I am a Postdoctoral Fellow at Harvard University working with Mor Nitzan and collaborating with Sergey Ovchinnikov. Moreover, I am fascinated by the quickly developing self-supervised and reinforcement learning fields.
title: Justas Dauparas

content:
I will be following the UC Berkeley’s CS294-158 Deep Unsupervised Learning course and sharing my short summaries and takeaways.
The course covers Deep Generative Models and Self-supervised Learning with the focus on the theoretical foundations as well as their newly enabled applications. Stay tuned!
Topics:
 Autoregressive Models Lossless Compression Flow Models Latent Variable Models Bits-Back Coding Implicit Models  Introduction
What is Unsupervised Learning??? It is a type of machine learning algorithm that draws inferences from data which does not have labeled responses, so no direct classification or regression can be done. * Generative Models * Self-supervised Learning (labels are given in a clever way), like time, one patch above the other.
Intelligence is all about compression.
Applications:
 General novel data Compression Improve downstream tasks Flexible building blocks for reusing in other problems  VAEs, GANs, zebras, bigGAN (maybe latent space is useful), styleGAN, WaveNet, video generation, text generation, compression (WaveOne vs JPEG), sentiment detection.

title: Unsupervised learning

summary: Submitted to the ICML Workshop on Computational Biology.
title: Unified framework for multivariate distributions in biological sequences

summary: We show that Q-learning with nonlinear Q-function and no explicit exploration can learn several standard benchmark tasks.
title: Depth and nonlinearity induce implicit exploration

summary: We discovered that motile cells in sessile colonies of peritrichously flagellated bacteria can self-organize into motile bands that can drive long-range fluid transport at a constant speed of ~30 Î¼m/s, providing a stable high-speed avenue for material transport at the colony scale.
title: Self-organization of swimmers drives long-range fluid transport in bacterial colonies

summary: My PhD work on Stokes flows near boundaries.
title: Stokes flows near boundaries: bacteria, corners, and pumps (PhD thesis)

summary: Theoretical and experimental work on understanding leading-order Stokes flows near a 3D corner.
title: Leading-order Stokes flows near a corner

summary: The rotation of a helical bacterial flagellum induces both a force and a torque on the surrounding fluid, both of which lead to a net flow along the surface.
title: Helical micropumps near surfaces

summary: We explain the systematic chiral flow in the clockwise direction ahead of the bacterial swarm.
title: Flagellar flows around bacterial swarms
